title.narrative: Integrated Farming Systems: Dairy, small livestock (indigenous chickens and goat)and Vegetable Production

description.narrative: The overall Project goal is to train 16 extension workers/ lead farmers active in the above mentioned 4 districts in horticulture/ poultry/ dairy and small ruminants management and improve the local value chains in the 4 districts including training of small holder farmers.

mailing-address.narrative: P.O. Box 29777, 2502 LT The Hague, The Netherlands

title.narrative: Project photo
Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities. Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. In the Grant Obligations and Conditions, the obligatory dates for submission of the annual/additional reports are mentioned. The final report must reflect on the entire project period.

title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative:
Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period.
+
In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative:
In this section (maximum 1000 words), please
**For TMT+:**
Comment to what extent the outputs have been achieved. Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

title.narrative: Narrative report

description.narrative: Reporting is an important management tool which is used to inform relevant government officials and other stakeholders about the results being achieved by individual projects and the programme as a whole. For project partners, it is compulsory to use the prescribed Orange Knowledge annual report format in order to report on project achievements. The annual report also provides valuable data on the financial situation of the project. Based on an analysis of the project performance in relation to the project output(s) and expected outcome(s), a revision of the project work plan may be suggested by the project partners. The consequences of a possible revision on the project work plan and budget must be made clear in the annual report. Nuffic monitors outputs and outcomes and not activities. Therefore, the main focus of the annual report must be on the achievement of the project’s output(s) and planned outcome(s). The information provided in the annual reports of the projects is used by Nuffic to monitor the progress of the project and to inform the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and other stakeholders about the output(s) and outcome(s) being achieved by individual projects and the Orange Knowledge programme as a whole. Please note that if project progress is in accordance with the original planning, reporting requirements are minimal. Only in case of deviations from the planning, more elaboration is demanded. title.narrative: 14. Final report TMT+/TMT

description.narrative: Final conclusions TMT+/TMT (in case of final report) Reflect on how the training has contributed to addressing the capacity needs as described by the requesting organisation in the proposal form. How effective and efficient has the TMT+ been in reaching the desired objectives? Please formulate lessons learned and recommendations for the post-project period. + In your email submitting the final report, the partners will enclose: - an inventory of equipment purchased - a document signed by the (Lead partner) Dutch consortium/provider and Lead partner consortium country A or requesting organisation on the transfer of ownership - a list with the names and email addresses of staff members who participated in staff training for their registration in the Holland Alumni Network database

actual.value:
A cross section of extension workers active in the NRDC working area participated in the TMT. Age varied from 29 to 52. This “mixture” of participants lead to good discussions and team work. During the training it became quickly clear that every topic and the approach used to transfer knowledge and skills were “eye openers” to all participants. For most it was also a good experience to work in teams comprising of men and women of different ages on assignments and exchanging experiences. A lot of ideas were developed on ways and means to improve the performance on the farms in their working area. In the time period between the main course and the assessment week the Aeres Coordinator received many pictures of participants working on assignments on farms in their working area. The teacher training component was also very new to most of the participants and a very good experience.
During the Modules on agricultural value chain analysis and development, covering all of the identified knowledge and skill gaps identified in the original TMT Proposal, students were made aware of the concept of agricultural value chains. They are able to describe and analyse existing value chains, the role of actors, service providers, administration(s) and policies (local, national and international). They are able to link these issues to their own situation. Attention was also given to quality control in the Value Chains. Participants are enthusiastic about the Value Chain concept, however, they understand that small holder farmer can only participate successfully in value chains if they have the basic knowledge and skills to run their farm as a business. During the TMT the principles of farm economics, management and entrepreneurship were explained and exercised. Use of key performance indicators for assessing/ analysing the technical and financial performance were explained and used in various, initial theoretical, exercises. Various categories of farmers were visited (small scale, emerging farmers, commercial farmers, male as well as female farmers) and students were assigned to analyse the technical as well as financial performance of these farms in groups and develop plans for improvement of the technical as well as the financial performance based on their observations and information collected from the farmers during the visits. Also gender related issues were included in the assignment. Each group was assigned a specific farm for their assignment and present their findings and recommendations. Also attention was given to various technical topics. In the last Module attention was given to “Training of Trainers” topics. Principles of competence based learning, developing short training programs for farmers/farm workers (in his/her area of expertise), developing a lesson plan (one training session) and implementation of the lesson plan developed. At the end of week 3 student were given the assignment to develop a short farmer training program in a step wise approach (in groups) which was monitored by Aeres. In week 4 feedback was provided to the work done and individual training performance assessed.
During the evaluation of the Course almost all participants acknowledged that they had learned a lot and that their way of training of emerging young commercial farmers would change and improve a lot.

title.narrative: 2. Project progress and achievement

description.narrative: In this section (maximum 1000 words), please **For TMT+:** Comment to what extent the outputs have been achieved. Comment on the activities that have taken place and the most important milestones.

actual.value:
A cross section of extension workers active in the NRDC working area participated in the TMT. Age varied from 29 to 52. This “mixture” of participants lead to good discussions and team work. During the training it became quickly clear that every topic and the approach used to transfer knowledge and skills were “eye openers” to all participants. For most it was also a good experience to work in teams comprising of men and women of different ages on assignments and exchanging experiences. A lot of ideas were developed on ways and means to improve the performance on the farms in their working area. In the time period between the main course and the assessment week the Aeres Coordinator received many pictures of participants working on assignments on farms in their working area. The teacher training component was also very new to most of the participants and a very good experience.
During the Modules on agricultural value chain analysis and development students were made aware of the concept of (dairy) value chains. They are able to describe and analyze existing value chains, the role of actors, service providers, administration(s) and policies (local, national and international). They are able to link these issues to their own situation. Attention was also given to quality control in the Value Chains. Participants are enthusiastic about the Value Chain concept, however, they understand that small holder farmer can only participate successfully in value chains if they have the basic knowledge and skills to run their farm as a business. During the TMT the principles of farm economics, management and entrepreneurship were explained and exercised. Use of key performance indicators for assessing/ analysing the technical and financial performance were explained and used in various, initial theoretical, exercises. Various categories of farmers were visited (small scale, emerging farmers, commercial farmers, male as well as female farmers) and students were assigned to analyse the technical as well as financial performance of these farms in groups and develop plans for improvement of the technical as well as the financial performance based on their observations and information collected from the farmers during the visits. Also gender related issues were included in the assignment. Each group was assigned a specific farm for their assignment and present their findings and recommendations. Also attention was given to various technical topics. In the last Module attention was given to “Training of Trainers” topics. Principles of competence based learning, developing short training programs for farmers/farm workers (in his/her area of expertise), developing a lesson plan (one training session) and implementation of the lesson plan developed. At the end of week 3 student were given the assignment to develop a short farmer training program in a step wise approach (in groups) which was monitored by Aeres. In week 4 feedback was provided to the work done and individual training performance assessed.
During the evaluation of the Course all participants acknowledged that they had learned a lot and that their way of training of emerging young commercial farmers would change and improve a lot.

title.narrative: B. Enhanced knowledge and skills of individuals and organisations (in partner countries and in the NL) in line with country/regional specific labour market needs & aiming at inclusiveness
B.I.2. % scholarship holder's /TMT participants / alumni satisfaction

comment.narrative: 27-10-2021: All modules were evaluated separately and all participants were very satisfied despite the online difficulties faced

title.narrative: B.I.9. % alumni / TMT participants who are promoted to a more strategic position post-study

comment.narrative: 27-10-2021: All participants continues to work as extension worker in their designated areas

title.narrative: B.I.1. Number of scholarship holders / TMT participants that have successfully completed course/training (male / female / minorities)

comment.narrative: 27-10-2021: At the start of the training some last minute changes had to be made because of Corona virus infections. One participant unfortunately died from Corona Virus after the initial training program of 3 weeks duration. After consultation with the local coordinator it was decided not to replace this participant.

title.narrative: B.O.3. Number of organisations with institutional mechanism for quality assurance

comment.narrative: 27-10-2021: Both NRDC and extension workers have increased their knowledge with regard to quality assurance.

title.narrative: B.I.7. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of minorities

comment.narrative: 27-10-2021: Female local coordinator made sure that all particpants felt secure and at ease during the implementation of the TMT

title.narrative: B.I.6. Number of stimulating measures/extra facilities aimed at preparation, supervision and aftercare of female candidates

comment.narrative: 27-10-2021: Female local coordinator made sure that female participants felt very safe and secure during the training and practical lessons/ assignments

title.narrative: B.O.1. Number of organisations strengthened by individual and/or group training

comment.narrative: 27-10-2021: NRDC College, the National extension service and Aeres trainers all acquired new experiences and insights during the implementation of the TMT.

title.narrative: B.I.5. % of scholarships awarded to minorities
B.I.3. % of scholarship holders / TMT participants / alumni employed post-study within region and same employer
B.I.8. % alumni / TMT participants who state that they have acquired new knowledge and skills; e.g. problem solving, effective communication
B.O.2. % of alumni / TMT participants who have applied the acquired knowledge and skills within their working environment
B.O.4. Number of organisations developed and implemented a gender strategy
B.I.4. % of scholarships awarded to women
B.I.11. Improved gender equality and gender awareness in the workplace

actual.value: Special lessons were organized on gender issues in agricultural value chains and making sure that farmer training programs are developed keeping gender equality in mind.

title.narrative: B.I.10. Changes in personal, academic and professional attitudes and attributes through training and education programmes

actual.value: The training has certainly contributed to a change in professional attitude towards developing and implementing farmer training and extension programs
